7.6 Americanized “Old School” Sheet Cake
This recipe captures the nostalgia of classic school dinners with a simple, robust sheet cake and the iconic “Pink Custard” made without specialty powders.

7.6.1 Ingredients

7.6.1.1 For the Cake

240g (2 cups) All-Purpose Flour (spooned and leveled if using volume measurements)
12g (3 tsp) Baking Powder
3g (1/2 tsp) Salt
227g (1 cup / 2 sticks) Unsalted Butter, softened
200g (1 cup) Granulated Sugar
4 Large Eggs, room temperature
10ml (2 tsp) Vanilla Extract
45ml (3 tbsp) Whole Milk



7.6.1.2 For the Thick White Icing

300g (2 1/2 cups) Powdered Sugar (Confectioners’ Sugar)
45–60ml (3–4 tbsp) Warm Water
Rainbow Sprinkles (jimmies or nonpareils)



7.6.1.3 For the Homemade “Pink Custard”

480ml (2 cups) Whole Milk
38g (3 tbsp) Sugar
16g (2 tbsp) Cornstarch (Cornflour)
5ml (1 tsp) Vanilla Extract
1 drop Red or Pink food coloring




7.6.2 Instructions

7.6.2.1 The Cake

Prep: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9x13-inch metal baking pan. For easy removal, line the bottom with parchment paper.
The “DIY Self-Rising” Mix: In a small bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt. This ensures the leavening is evenly distributed so your cake doesn’t have “craters.”
Creaming: In a large bowl, cream the softened butter and sugar together until pale and fluffy (about 3 minutes with a hand mixer).
Combine: Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each. Stir in the vanilla.
Fold: Gradually add the flour mixture. Once combined, stir in the milk to reach a smooth, “dropping” consistency.
Bake: Spread into the pan and bake for 25–30 minutes. A toothpick inserted into the center should come out clean. Cool completely in the pan.



7.6.2.2 The Icing

Mix: Whisk the powdered sugar and warm water (start with 45ml/3 tbsp, add more if needed) until it’s the consistency of thick toothpaste.
Decorate: Pour over the completely cooled cake and spread with an offset spatula. Add sprinkles immediately before the icing sets.



7.6.2.3 The Pink Custard

The Slurry: In a small cup, mix the cornstarch with 45ml (3 tbsp) of the cold milk until it’s a smooth liquid with no lumps.
Heat: Pour the rest of the milk and the sugar into a saucepan. Heat over medium until it just starts to simmer (steaming, with small bubbles at the edges).
Thicken: Pour the cornstarch slurry into the hot milk while whisking constantly.
Finish: Continue to cook for 1–2 minutes as it thickens. Remove from heat and stir in the vanilla and food coloring. It will thicken further as it sits!




7.6.3 Chef’s Notes

Internal Temperature: If you are using an instant-read thermometer, pull the cake when it reaches 200°F (93°C). There will be a few degrees of “carry-over” cooking as it cools in the pan, which will bring it to the perfect final temperature (205°F (96°C)) without drying it out.

7.7 The Food Charlatan’s Snickerdoodles
Attribution: My Favorite Snickerdoodles by Karen from The Food Charlatan.
These are widely considered the quintessential Snickerdoodles: pillowy soft, tangy from the cream of tartar, and coated in a generous layer of cinnamon sugar. They have that classic “cracked earth” look and a texture that stays soft for days.

7.7.1 Yields
2–3 Dozen Cookies


7.7.2 Prep Time
20 Minutes


7.7.3 Bake Time
8–10 Minutes


7.7.4 Ingredients

7.7.4.1 For the Dough

350g (2 3/4 cups) All-Purpose Flour (spooned and leveled)
8g (2 tsp) Cream of Tartar
6g (1 tsp) Baking Soda
3g (1/2 tsp) Salt
227g (1 cup / 2 sticks) Unsalted Butter, softened
300g (1 1/2 cups) Granulated Sugar
2 Large Eggs
10ml (2 tsp) Vanilla Extract



7.7.4.2 For the Cinnamon-Sugar Coating

67g (1/3 cup) Granulated Sugar
15g (2 tbsp) Ground Cinnamon




7.7.5 Instructions

Prep: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone mats.
Dry Mix: In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, cream of tartar, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.
Cream: In a large bowl (or stand mixer), cream the softened butter and 300g (1 1/2 cups) sugar together until light and fluffy (about 2–3 minutes).
Wet Mix: Add the eggs one at a time, beating well after each. Stir in the vanilla.
Combine: Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture. Mix until just combined. The dough will be thick.
Make Coating: In a small bowl, whisk together the coating sugar and cinnamon.
Shape: Scoop the dough into 1.5-tablespoon balls. Roll each ball generously in the cinnamon-sugar mixture to coat completely.
Bake: Place balls 2 inches apart on the baking sheets. Bake for 8–10 minutes.

Visual Cue: They should look set and puffy, but still soft in the center. The edges should be barely golden.

Cool: Let cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack. They will deflate slightly and develop their signature crackled surface as they cool.



7.7.6 Chef’s Notes

Cream of Tartar: This is essential for the signature tangy flavor and chewy texture. If you absolutely cannot find it, you can replace both the cream of tartar (2 tsp) and the baking soda (1 tsp) with 3 teaspoons (12g) of baking powder. Warning: The result will be slightly cakier and lack the classic Snickerdoodle tang, but you’ll have a decent cinnamon-sugar cookie.
Don’t Overbake: These cookies rely on being slightly underbaked to maintain their softness. If they look wet, bake a minute longer. If they look dry, you’ve gone too far.
Internal Temperature: If you are technically inclined, you can pull these when the internal temperature registers between 175°F - 180°F (79°C - 82°C). They will finish setting as they cool.

8.1 Boardwalk Lemonade
Attribution: Replicated from Ocean City, NJ boardwalk lemonade.

title: 8  Drinks

8.1.1 Ingredients

240ml freshly squeezed lemon juice (about 4-6 large lemons)
200g granulated sugar
960-1200ml cold water (adjust to taste)
Ice


8.1.1.1 For Garnish

Optional: lemon slices for garnish




8.1.2 Instructions

Make a Simple Syrup: In a small saucepan, combine 200g of sugar and 240ml of water. Heat over medium-low heat, stirring until the sugar is completely dissolved. Do not boil. Remove from heat and let it cool to room temperature. This step is crucial for “state fair” quality lemonade, as it prevents a gritty texture from undissolved sugar.
Juice the Lemons: While the simple syrup cools, squeeze your lemons to get about 240ml of fresh lemon juice. Roll the lemons on the counter before cutting them in half to help extract more juice. Strain out any seeds or excessive pulp if you prefer.
Combine Ingredients: In a large pitcher, combine the cooled simple syrup and the fresh lemon juice.
Add Water and Adjust: Gradually add 720-960ml of cold water, stirring well after each addition. Taste the lemonade as you go and adjust the amount of water to achieve your desired level of sweetness and tartness. Some prefer a stronger, more tart lemonade, while others like it sweeter.
Chill and Serve: For best results, chill the lemonade in the refrigerator for at least an hour before serving. This allows the flavors to meld and ensures it’s refreshingly cold. Serve over ice, with lemon slices for garnish if desired.

Note: You can add some lemon zest to the syrup for extra flavor. You can also use bottled lemon juice instead of fresh if time is a factor.

8.2 Pumpkin Spice Latte
This recipe is based on research to replicate the Starbucks Pumpkin Spice Latte at home.

8.2.1 For the Pumpkin Spice Sauce
This recipe makes enough for 6-8 drinks.

8.2.1.1 Ingredients

397g (1 can) sweetened condensed milk
80g (1/3 cup) pumpkin purée
5g (1 tsp) pumpkin pie spice
2.5g (1/2 tsp) ground cinnamon
5ml (1 tsp) vanilla extract



8.2.1.2 Instructions

Combine condensed milk, pumpkin purée, spices, and vanilla extract in a small saucepan.
Warm the mixture over medium heat for approximately 4 minutes, whisking continually until the ingredients are completely homogeneous and the mixture is hot, but not boiling rapidly.
Remove from heat. Blend using an immersion blender.
Allow to cool. Store the concentrate in an airtight container in the refrigerator.




8.2.2 For the Latte
This recipe makes one latte.

8.2.2.1 Ingredients

30-60ml (2-4 tbsp) Pumpkin Spice Sauce
14-18g finely ground coffee
50-60ml hot water (98°C / 208°F)
200-300ml milk



8.2.2.2 Garnish

Whipped cream
Pumpkin spice topping (cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, cloves)



8.2.2.3 Instructions

Place the Pumpkin Spice Sauce into a serving mug.
Brew the coffee concentrate using an Aeropress with the hot water, plunging the finished liquid directly into the mug. Stir vigorously to dissolve the sauce.
Heat the milk to 60-70°C (140-160°F) and froth using a French Press.
Pour the frothed milk over the coffee/sauce mixture.
Top with whipped cream and a sprinkle of pumpkin spice topping.

8.3.2 Instructions

Separate Eggs: Carefully separate the egg yolks and whites into two large bowls.
Prepare Yolks: Beat the egg yolks with half of the sugar until light and creamy.
Prepare Whites: In the other bowl, beat the egg whites until they form stiff peaks. Gradually beat in the remaining half of the sugar until the mixture is glossy.
Combine Mixtures: Gently fold the yolk mixture into the beaten egg whites. Be careful not to deflate the whites.
Add Milk and Vanilla: Slowly stir in the milk and vanilla extract.
Add Cream: Stir in half of the heavy cream.
Whip Remaining Cream: In a separate bowl, whip the remaining half of the cream until it forms soft peaks.
Fold in Whipped Cream: Gently fold the whipped cream into the eggnog mixture.
Serve: Serve chilled or at room temperature with a sprinkle of ground nutmeg.



8.3.3 Chef’s Notes

On Raw Eggs: This recipe uses raw eggs. If you are concerned about salmonella, it is recommended to use pasteurized eggs.
Alcoholic Version: For a traditional boozy eggnog, per batch: replace 480ml (2 cups) of the milk with 240ml (1 cup) of white rum and 240ml (1 cup) of whiskey (Bourbon or Canadian). Add the alcohol along with the remaining milk in step 5.
Leftovers: Leftover eggnog makes excellent French toast batter.
